title: 113_hr2361
content:
The Act titled "Protecting Honest, Everyday Americans from Senseless And Needless Taxes (PHEASANT) Act of 2013" aims to prevent unnecessary taxes. The Congress finds that the Second Amendment includes the right to acquire firearms and ammunition without undue burdens, and local taxes on these items inhibit this right. Congress has the authority to regulate interstate commerce in firearms and ammunition to prevent suppression of access to these products. The purpose of this Act is to prevent States or local jurisdictions from using taxation to suppress lawful interstate commerce and constitutional activities, particularly affecting low-income communities' access to firearms and ammunition for self-defense, which infringes on the Second Amendment. Limitation on state and local taxes on sales of firearms and ammunition to prevent suppression of lawful commerce and access to self-defense tools. No State or local government may impose new taxes on firearms or ammunition that affect interstate commerce, or increase existing taxes on such sales. The Act prohibits State or local governments from imposing new taxes on firearms or ammunition that affect interstate commerce or increasing existing taxes on such sales. Limitation on state and local taxes for background checks related to firearm and ammunition sales. No State or local government may impose a tax on background checks for firearm or ammunition sales related to interstate commerce, or increase the tax rate for such checks. No State or local government may impose a tax on background checks for firearm or ammunition sales related to interstate commerce. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. For purposes of this Act, "ammunition," "background check," "firearm," "local government," and "sale" are defined as specified in relevant sections of the United States Code and State laws. In this context, "sale" is defined as the transfer, sell, trade, or give for value of a firearm. Additionally, "State" refers to any of the States, the District of Columbia, or any commonwealth, territory, or possession of the United States. Lastly, "tax" is defined as a fee payable to the State or local government. SEC. 6. SEVERABILITY.

If any provision of this Act is deemed unconstitutional, the remaining provisions and their application shall not be affected.

SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICATION OF ACT.

Effective Date: This Act takes effect upon enactment, except for taxes accrued before enactment or ongoing tax-related litigation.
